title: Ebina, Kanagawa
text:
is a <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> located in <a href="Kanagawa%20Prefecture">Kanagawa Prefecture</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>., the city had an estimated <a href="population">population</a> of 136,312 and a <a href="population%20density">population density</a> of 5100 persons per km2. The total area of the city is .
Geography.
Ebina is located approximately 50 kilometers from central Tokyo and 20 kilometers from Yokohama. The city is roughly rectangular, 8.7 kilometers north-to-south by 6.15 kilometers east-to-west, with an elevation of 11 to 84 meters above sea level. It is in the middle of the <a href="Sagami%20Plain">Sagami Plain</a>, part of western <a href="Kant%C5%8D%20Plain">Kantō Plain</a>. The city sits on the eastern bank of the <a href="Sagami%20River">Sagami River</a>, and the <a href="Hikiji%20River">Hikiji River</a> flows through part of the city. The <a href="T%C5%8Dmei%20Expressway">Tōmei Expressway</a> cuts across the southern end of the city.
Surrounding municipalities.
Kanagawa Prefecture
Climate.
Ebina has a <a href="Humid%20subtropical%20climate">Humid subtropical climate</a> (Köppen "Cfa") characterized by warm summers and cool winters with light to no snowfall. The average annual temperature in Ebina is 15.2 °C. The average annual rainfall is 1632 mm with September as the wettest month. The temperatures are highest on average in August, at around 25.6 °C, and lowest in January, at around 5.2 °C.
Demographics.
Per Japanese census data, the population of Ebina has grown steadily over the past century.
History.
The area of modern Ebina has been settled since prehistoric times, and has a number of remains from the <a href="Kofun%20period">Kofun period</a>. Ebina became the <a href="kokufu">provincial capital</a> of <a href="Sagami%20Province">Sagami Province</a> in the <a href="Nara%20period">Nara period</a>, and was the location of the "kokubunji", or <a href="provincial%20temple">provincial temple</a>. It was home to the Yokoyama clan, one of the seven warrior clans of the <a href="Musashi%20Province">Musashi region</a> during the early <a href="Kamakura%20period">Kamakura period</a>. During the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a>, the lands around Ebina were "<a href="tenry%C5%8D">tenryō</a>" territory theoretically administered directly by the <a href="Tokugawa%20Shogunate">Tokugawa Shogunate</a> in <a href="Edo">Edo</a>; however, in reality, the area was a patchwork of small fiefs held by various "<a href="hatamoto">hatamoto</a>", as well as exclaves under the control of <a href="Sakura%20Domain">Sakura Domain</a> and <a href="Karasuyama%20Domain">Karasuyama Domain</a>.
After the <a href="Meiji%20Restoration">Meiji Restoration</a>, the area became part of <a href="K%C5%8Dza%20District%2C%20Kanagawa">Kōza District</a>, Kanagawa Prefecture and was administratively divided into Ebina Village and Arima Village on April 1, 1889 with the establishment of the modern municipalities system. The area was connected by rail in 1926 via the <a href="Sagami%20Railway">Sagami Railway</a> and in 1927 by the <a href="Odakyu%20Electric%20Railway">Odakyu Electric Railway</a>, leading to an increase in population and a change in status of Ebina from village to town in 1940. In 1955, Arima Village merged into Ebina Town. Ebina was elevated to <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> status on November 1, 1971. Urban development projects in the 1980s and 1990s have modernized the city center.
Government.
Ebina has a <a href="mayor-council">mayor-council</a> form of government with a directly elected mayor and a <a href="unicameral">unicameral</a> city council of 22 members. Ebina contributes one member to the Kanagawa Prefectural Assembly. In terms of national politics, the city is part of Kanagawa 13th district of the <a href="House%20of%20Representatives%20of%20Japan">lower house</a> of the <a href="Diet%20of%20Japan">Diet of Japan</a>.
Economy.
Ebina is home to over 150 factories. The town is a center of the production of <a href="electrical%20appliance">electrical appliance</a>s, metal products, and <a href="machinery">machinery</a>. The <a href="Taito%20Corporation">Taito Corporation</a> operates the Ebina Development Center in Ebina. The city was once known for its broad <a href="paddy%20field">rice paddies</a>, but agriculture now centers on the cultivation of strawberries, tomatoes, and ornamental plants. Ebina serves as a bedroom community to the greater Tokyo and Yokohama area.
Education.
Ebina has 13 public elementary schools and six public middle schools operated by the city government. The city has three public high schools operated by the Kanagawa Prefectural Board of Education, and the prefecture also operates two special education schools for the handicapped.
